title: Lord Sugar wasn't impressed on The Apprentice, by JIM SHELLEY
text:
The Apprentice was basically a lesson in how to ruin an ice-lolly. And then mess up selling them.

Viewers who remembered making them as kids (filling lolly-shaped moulds with juice then putting them in the freezer) and thought the task was easy had forgotten one thing: this was The Apprentice.

Even then it seemed difficult to see how anyone could spoil an ice-lolly (surely one of life’s most perfect foods) or imagine a flavor you didn’t like.

Unimpressed: The Apprentice was basically a lesson in how to ruin an ice-lolly. And then mess up selling them

Personally, the appeal of Mini Milk ice-lollies was always hard to understand – certainly compared to Fab, Rocket, Calippo, Solero, Fruit Split, even a Twister.

The Apprentice soon changed that.

‘What goes with cherry Cola?’ the girls’ Project Manager asked her colleagues as they sampled ingredients at ‘a high-end ice-lolly company in West London. (Where else?)

‘What about cream cheese?’ wondered Lubna, possibly the last thing I (and hopefully you) would have said.

Eventually they settled on a theme of ‘retro sweet’ ice-lollies - made of cherry Cola and glace cherries with ‘pieces of liquorice Allsorts in them.’

This was so retro some of the gals didn’t actually know what liquorice was.

Ooer: The boys' phallic lollies made the girls' cherry Cola and liquorice flavour appealing

‘But would kids like it?’ fretted Jemelin, correctly sensing the answer was No. Definitely not.

Nonetheless this was their ice-lolly to sell to the public. For the corporate client, their ‘gourmet’ product consisted of ‘edible flowers and grapes with sprigs of rosemary.’

(Again, yuck.)

Almost impressively, they managed to make these taste even more unappetizing than they sounded.

‘I tried one,’ Karren Brady testified, pulling an unpleasant face. ‘And had a big lump of rosemary in my mouth. It was like eating a garden!’

Quite.

As for the boys, for reasons of their own, the flavor of their prototype lolly was ‘blueberry and activated charcoal.’

Unpleasant: Lord Sugar derided the boys' effort as ‘looking like a pig’s trotter’, ‘like a bit of medical waste’, and ‘as if Ann Summers has gone into the ice-cream business

Unappetising: The girls settled on a theme of ‘retro sweet’ ice-lollies - made of cherry Cola and glace cherries with pieces of liquorice Allsorts in them

They sensibly rejected this, opting instead for ‘blueberries, stem ginger, lavender, and beetroot’ – which was worse. (Give me charcoal any day – activated or otherwise.)

The actual taste of their ‘deluxe’ ice-lolly (raspberry, coconut milk, and edible glitter) didn’t come into it.

Lord Sugar derided it as ‘looking like a pig’s trotter’, ‘like a bit of medical waste’, and ‘as if Ann Summers has gone into the ice-cream business.’

Or as Ryan-Mark Parsons lamented, more succinctly: ‘the lolly looks like a penis!’

The buyer from their corporate client certainly thought so.

‘I’m just going to leave it there…’ she said, putting it back on the table, having suddenly realized she really didn’t want to be on primetime television sucking something pink and phallic.

Unfortunately, the glitter (that the boys assumed would provide the ‘glamour’ to justify their intended price of £3.85) had ‘disappeared’ in the coconut milk, sadly denying us the chance of seeing an ice-lolly resembling a glittery penis.

‘I don’t deal with glitter!’ Project Manager Kenna Ngoma protested, which seemed reasonable but avoided a more pertinent detail: his job.

‘I specialize in alcohol-infused ice-cream so this is what I do on a daily basis,’ he’d told the boys, adding perhaps unwisely: ‘for me this is quite easy!’

Kenna becoming Team Leader was clearly ‘a no-brainer’ – ‘being in the industry’ and, as he said, ‘having an understanding from an ice cream and lolly perspective.’

It seemed surprising that for ‘the trend which would be easier to sell’, he chose ‘the healthy option’ – considering he was ‘in the industry’, not to mention his understanding ‘from an ice cream and lolly perspective.’

‘What goes with cherry Cola?’ the girls’ Project Manager asked her colleagues as they sampled ingredients at ‘a high-end ice-lolly company in West London

Less surprisingly, the candidates didn’t fare much better selling these abominations, particularly to their corporate customers.

The girls’ team for example kept leaving the room during their meeting (to discuss what price to push for) but then couldn’t actually calculate the total anyway when they returned.

‘So you were a bit like Theresa May with Brexit! You went off and came back in with the same deal!’ scoffed Lord Sugar.

Sports agent Dean Ahmad also got in a muddle attempting to negotiate a deal for the boys’ upmarket product.

‘So you’re doubling the quantity and the price has gone up?’ the client scoffed in disbelief.

When the buyer saw the finished article, inevitably she concluded the sex lollies were ‘not premium’, which was rather an understatement (putting it politely). She then said she could only pay £1 - per item, not for the entire batch (90).

‘£3.50!’ Dean countered which, naturally, she rejected.

‘Absolutely no way…’ she smiled.

In hot water: Sports agent Dean Ahmad also got in a muddle attempting to negotiate a deal for the boys’ upmarket product

‘What about halfway? £1.25?’

‘Absolutely no way…’ she insisted, no longer smiling and repeating her offer of a pound, which, amazingly, he also rejected, inexplicably saying ‘brilliant, thank you!’, shaking hands, and promptly leaving.

Lord Sugar had compared the candidates’ efforts to Brexit. If the task was a metaphor for Britain’s entrepreneurs and the country’s prospects in a post-EU economy, the results did not bode well.

The girls’ profit of £545.20p, compared to £371.43p, gave them a win by £174.

It also meant they had each made just £34 per day for their endeavours and the boys only £26.

‘This task was a disaster!’ Lord Sugar lambasted them. ‘I have never in the whole of the time I’ve been in this boardroom come across a situation where a customer who’s disappointed, says ‘I’ll give you this amount of money’ and you walk away!’

It was the second week in succession that Dean had been blamed by the boys’ Project Manager for the team losing the task.

'It is unforgiveable that you lost the potential of £300 worth profit,’ Sugar told Dean, the hapless sub-team leader and corporate negotiator who had snubbed an offer of £1 per sex lolly that was frankly generous.

‘It is unforgiveable. Unforgiveable!’

But, even more unforgivably, it obviously wasn’t.

In time-honoured style on The Apprentice, at the last second, the boss switched tack.‘Kenna, you screwed it up!’ Lord Sugar snarled, and fired him instead.
